Triggering Event: At 7 AM, she rushed into the locker room at the hospital, heart pounding. A colleague mentioned a sudden influx of critical patients overnight; no one had called her for backup despite her being on-call. She felt a wave of anxiety, fearing she'd missed vital moments with her late husband's patients, those now fighting for their lives in her care.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, what if I was too late to help them? What if they died because I didn't show up fast enough? What if I couldn't save them? What if I messed up? What if I wasn't there when they needed me most? My mind is racing with all these scenarios. I feel so guilty that I might have missed crucial moments. I'm just so scared that I'll make mistakes again. What if I can't handle it anymore? What if I break down under pressure? What if I get fired? What if I lose everything? I wish I could go back in time and be there sooner. I wish I could change things somehow. I keep thinking about all the people who are struggling right now, and I don’t know how to reach them. My head is spinning with worst-case scenarios. I’m just so worried that I won’t be able to do anything. What if I fail completely?

In many ways, this unexpected outcome feels like a bitter reminder that one's efforts are often insufficient to meet society's needs. Triggering Event: Every evening, she'd sit alone in their old house, now hers alone. The clock hands moved slower than ever. She clicked through photo albums on her tablet, each picture a echo of happier times. Today, she stumbled upon one from their 50th wedding anniversary. His smile was still bright, but his eyes were already distant. She closed the album, unable to bear the weight of memories that now felt like failures. The house creaked around her, whispering reminders of emptiness.
Generated Assessment: As I sit here, surrounded by the echoes of my past, I can't help but feel the crushing weight of loneliness. Her life is so much more fulfilling than mine. Why must it be this way? It's as if every step forward for her is accompanied by two steps back for me. What's worse is when I try to recall happy moments, they're tainted by the knowledge of what could have been. It's all so unfair—my life is a series of missed opportunities, while hers is a tapestry woven with love and success. I'm just a thread, weak and frayed, slowly unraveling in the wind. She moves through time, leaving behind a trail of happiness, each moment building on the last, filling her heart with joy that I can only dream of. I'm just a shadow, always lagging behind, never able to catch up. Even in death, he'll find peace, surrounded by loved ones, while I'm left here, drowning in sorrow, forever lost in regret. The world keeps moving, and yet I remain stuck in this sea of longing, unable to escape the tide of what could have been.

Triggering Event: He noticed the new sous chef, barely out of culinary school, preparing his signature dish with practiced ease. A familiar pang of insecurity gnawed at him; he'd once moved with that same confidence. Now, every mistake felt magnified, every plate returned a harsh criticism echoing in his mind. He watched as the young man received praise from diners and staff alike, feeling more like an outsider in his own kitchen than ever before.
Generated Assessment: He was so damned excited to see the sous chef finally settling into the role he had been eyeing for months. The way he effortlessly plated dishes, how he seemed to intuitively know what worked together—this was exactly what I wanted to be doing. But then, the sous chef messed up. Big time. He overcooked a sauce, and it tasted like someone poured ketchup directly onto a piece of leather. It was disgusting. And yet, somehow, the restaurant's owner praised the kid, saying something about "taking risks" and "pushing boundaries." What the fuck? How could he do this to me? To us? This guy is a disaster waiting to happen, and now everyone thinks he's some kind of genius? I'm sick of it. Sick of being stuck here, watching him bask in attention while I struggle to keep up. You think it's easy trying to recreate the dishes we used to make when you can't even get the basics right? When I've spent years perfecting recipes and techniques, and this...this...kid comes along and screws everything up? It's infuriating. Triggering Event: At the office holiday party, she watched him laugh with their coworker, Lisa, their heads bent close together over shared secrets and jokes. She felt her stomach twist as she realized it was the same way he'd once laughed with her.

Triggering Event: "After a long, exhausting shift at the store, he found his car's tires slashed in the dimly lit parking lot. He could feel the rage building as he realized this wasn't an accident - it was malicious."
Generated Assessment: "I'm telling you, I knew this would happen! Who needs to check for tire slasher tools when they're out there looking for trouble? And why did it have to happen tonight? It makes no sense. You'd think someone with common decency wouldn't go through with something like this, but nope, here we are. This is exactly how I thought it would go down. I can already see myself dealing with all the stress of trying to find another ride home because my own stupid car is now useless. The worst part? We'll probably get blamed for it even though we didn't do anything wrong. Just great, just great."

Triggering Event: He found an old, faded photograph tucked into the cookbook he hadn't used in years. It was of him and his wife, laughing together at their first restaurant opening, before the late nights and constant travel had worn them down. He felt a familiar bitterness rise in his throat as he remembered her words, "We're just growing apart."
Generated Assessment: **“What should have happened? What should have been? What should she have said?”** He thought about all the times she’d made him feel like he wasn’t enough. All the moments where he'd struggled to keep up with her ambition. The memories of her standing by herself while he worked tirelessly behind the scenes, never taking credit for anything he did. She should’ve stayed. She should’ve seen things from his perspective. She should’ve understood how hard it was to balance everything—work, family, personal life. But instead, she chose to leave, leaving him alone once again. Why did she choose to focus so much on her career? Why did she want to spend every waking moment working? Shouldn’t she have prioritized our relationship over her ambitions? Shouldn’t she have stayed? As he looked through the photo album, he couldn’t help but think of what could have been if only she had seen things differently. If only she had chosen him over her work. If only she had realized that being there for her husband was important too. But now she's gone, and he’s left to pick up the pieces of a life that feels empty and meaningless. And he can't help but wonder what would've happened if she had stayed. This is a subjective reaction reflecting the cognitive distortion 'Should Statements'. Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, his hands trembling slightly, struggles to assemble a new display case in the quiet of his apartment. The instructions lie scattered around him, their tiny print illegible through his misting eyes. He feels a familiar pang of helplessness as he drops another screw into an inaccessible corner. The clock ticks on, indifferent to his frustration.
Generated Assessment: It’s just a damn display case. I can’t even remember why I bought it anyway. It looks like something from a 90s time capsule. I swear, I had it assembled in no time if I didn’t have those fucking stupid instructions. They’re probably printed in Braille by now. What’s the point? It doesn’t matter how long it takes. This is all just an excuse for me to avoid doing anything else. I’ve been putting off this project for weeks, but I guess I finally decided it was time to get my ass in gear. I mean, what’s the worst that could happen? It’s not like it’s going to fall apart right away. It’s not like it’s going to take me years to figure out how to fix it. Like fuck, I can barely put together IKEA furniture, let alone some fucking display case. This whole thing is a joke. You know, I feel so much better now that I’ve said all this shit out loud. Maybe I’ll go grab a beer after this. Yeah, that sounds perfect.
